Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Chrome on Windows 11 may be able to impersonate the context of Internet in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Chrome on Windows 11 May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
Description: Internet may be able to remotely execute code for Chrome on Windows 11.

Title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Chrome on Windows 11
Description: An attacker may pass data into Chrome on Windows 11 in order to change the flow of program execution within Chrome on Windows 11 to the attacker's choosing.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Chrome on Android may be able to impersonate the context of Internet in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Chrome on Android May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
Description: Internet may be able to remotely execute code for Chrome on Android.
Justification: [RS]:Apply strict input validation, enforce sandboxing, and keep Chrome on Android updated to prevent remote code execution.

Title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Chrome on Android
Description: An attacker may pass data into Chrome on Android in order to change the flow of program execution within Chrome on Android to the attacker's choosing.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server may be able to impersonate the context of Internet in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
Description: Internet may be able to remotely execute code for Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server.

Title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server
Description: An attacker may pass data into Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server in order to change the flow of program execution within Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server to the attacker's choosing.

Title: Cross Site Request Forgery
Description: Cross-site request forgery (CSRF or XSRF) is a type of attack in which an attacker forces a user's browser to make a forged request to a vulnerable site by exploiting an existing trust relationship between the browser and the vulnerable web site.  In a simple scenario, a user is logged in to web site A using a cookie as a credential.  The other browses to web site B.  Web site B returns a page with a hidden form that posts to web site A.  Since the browser will carry the user's cookie to web site A, web site B now can take any action on web site A, for example, adding an admin to an account.  The attack can be used to exploit any requests that the browser automatically authenticates, e.g. by session cookie, integrated authentication, IP whitelisting, …  The attack can be carried out in many ways such as by luring the victim to a site under control of the attacker, getting the user to click a link in a phishing email, or hacking a reputable web site that the victim will visit. The issue can only be resolved on the server side by requiring that all authenticated state-changing requests include an additional piece of secret payload (canary or CSRF token) which is known only to the legitimate web site and the browser and which is protected in transit through SSL/TLS. See the Forgery Protection property on the flow stencil for a list of mitigations.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Spotify may be able to impersonate the context of Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server may be able to impersonate the context of Spotify in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Spoofing of the Internet External Destination Entity
Description: Internet may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of Internet. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Spoofing the Internet External Entity
Description: Internet may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Chrome on Windows 11. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Spoofing of the Internet External Destination Entity
Description: Internet may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of Internet. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Spoofing the Internet External Entity
Description: Internet may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Chrome on Android. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
Justification: [RS]:Use strong authentication mechanisms like mutual TLS to verify the identity of external internet entities before granting access to Chrome on Android.

Title: Spoofing the Internet External Entity
Description: Internet may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Spoofing of the Internet External Destination Entity
Description: Internet may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of Internet. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Spoofing of Destination Data Store PostgreSQL 15
Description: PostgreSQL 15 may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being written to the attacker's target instead of PostgreSQL 15. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination data store.

Title: Spoofing of Source Data Store PostgreSQL 15
Description: PostgreSQL 15 may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to incorrect data delivered to Spotify. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source data store.

Title: Cross Site Scripting
Description: The web server 'Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server' could be a subject to a cross-site scripting attack because it does not sanitize untrusted input.

Title: Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server Process Memory Tampered
Description: If Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server is given access to memory, such as shared memory or pointers, or is given the ability to control what Spotify executes (for example, passing back a function pointer.), then Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server can tamper with Spotify. Consider if the function could work with less access to memory, such as passing data rather than pointers. Copy in data provided, and then validate it.

Title: Cross Site Scripting
Description: The web server 'Spotify' could be a subject to a cross-site scripting attack because it does not sanitize untrusted input.

Title: Cross Site Scripting
Description: The web server 'Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server' could be a subject to a cross-site scripting attack because it does not sanitize untrusted input.

Title: Potential SQL Injection Vulnerability for PostgreSQL 15
Description: SQL injection is an attack in which malicious code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server for parsing and execution. Any procedure that constructs SQL statements should be reviewed for injection vulnerabilities because SQL Server will execute all syntactically valid queries that it receives. Even parameterized data can be manipulated by a skilled and determined attacker.
Justification: [RS]:Use parameterized queries and input validation to prevent SQL injection vulnerabilities in SQL statements.

Title: Cross Site Scripting
Description: The web server 'Spotify' could be a subject to a cross-site scripting attack because it does not sanitize untrusted input.

Title: Persistent Cross Site Scripting
Description: The web server 'Spotify' could be a subject to a persistent cross-site scripting attack because it does not sanitize data store 'PostgreSQL 15' inputs and output.

Title: External Entity Internet Potentially Denies Receiving Data
Description: Internet claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

Title: Potential Data Repudiation by Chrome on Windows 11
Description: Chrome on Windows 11 claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

Title: External Entity Internet Potentially Denies Receiving Data
Description: Internet claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

Title: Potential Data Repudiation by Chrome on Android
Description: Chrome on Android claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

Title: Potential Data Repudiation by Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server
Description: Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

Title: External Entity Internet Potentially Denies Receiving Data
Description: Internet claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
Justification: [RS]:Enable logging and auditing to capture the source, timestamp, and summary of all data transmitted across the trust boundary to the Internet.

Title: Weak Access Control for a Resource
Description: Improper data protection of PostgreSQL 15 can allow an attacker to read information not intended for disclosure. Review authorization settings.
Justification: [RS]:Enforce role-based access controls and regularly review PostgreSQL 15 authorization and encryption settings to protect sensitive data.

Title: Data Flow Login Request, Search Query Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Chrome on Windows 11
Description: Chrome on Windows 11 crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.

Title: Data Flow HTTPS Response Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: Data Flow Login Request, Search Query Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Chrome on Android
Description: Chrome on Android crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.

Title: Data Flow HTTPS Response Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server
Description: Apache Tomcat Web & Application Server crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.

Title: Data Flow HTTPS Request Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: Data Flow HTTPS Response Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
Justification: [RS]:Use encryption (e.g., TLS) and message integrity checks to protect data in transit across trust boundaries from interception or tampering.

Title: Potential Excessive Resource Consumption for Spotify or PostgreSQL 15
Description: Does Spotify or PostgreSQL 15 take explicit steps to control resource consumption? Resource consumption attacks can be hard to deal with, and there are times that it makes sense to let the OS do the job. Be careful that your resource requests don't deadlock, and that they do timeout.
